meanings.sent1: The teacher will condemn cheating in the exam.
meanings.sent2: The community came together to condemn the act of vandalism.
meanings.sent3: The talking parrot learned to condemn bad behavior with a loud squawk.
meanings.sent4: Her eyes seemed to condemn his every move, silently judging him.
meanings.sent5: The judge's stern look seemed to condemn the defendant before any words were spoken.

meanings.definition: Sentence (someone) to a particular punishment, especially death
meanings.sent1: The court may condemn the criminal to life in prison.
meanings.sent2: In some countries, the law allows to condemn individuals to death penalty.
meanings.sent3: The magician jokingly tried to condemn his assistant to a day of cleaning up after the show.
meanings.sent4: The ancient curse seemed to condemn the treasure hunters to eternal misfortune.
meanings.sent5: The king's decree would condemn any who dared to defy him to a fate worse than death.

meanings.definition: Declare (something) to be wrong or evil
meanings.sent1: The wise elder would often condemn acts of greed in the village.
meanings.sent2: It is important to condemn any form of discrimination in society.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous kitten seemed to condemn the new vacuum cleaner as its mortal enemy.
meanings.sent4: The haunting melody seemed to condemn the listener to a state of melancholy.
meanings.sent5: The ancient scroll seemed to condemn anyone who dared to read it, unleashing a curse upon them.
